name: Shuri Castle
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage Site and former palace of the Ryukyu Kingdom, currently undergoing restoration after the 2019 fire with completion expected in 2026.
description:
Shuri Castle is a Ryukyuan gusuku castle located in the historic Shuri district of Naha. Between 1429 and 1879, it served as the palace of the Ryukyu Kingdom and was the political, economic, and cultural heart of the Ryukyu Islands.

The castle's distinctive red-lacquered architecture was influenced by Chinese palaces like the Forbidden City in Beijing, reflecting Okinawa's historical ties with China. The site includes the iconic Shureimon gate, which is featured on Japan's 2,000 yen note.

Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000 as part of the Gusuku Sites and Related Properties of the Kingdom of Ryukyu, the castle was tragically destroyed by fire in October 2019. Visitors can currently observe the valuable reconstruction process, with the main hall expected to be fully restored by autumn 2026.

name: Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium
short_description: One of the world's largest aquariums famous for its massive Kuroshio Sea tank housing whale sharks and manta rays.
description:
The Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium is considered one of the best aquariums in Japan and ranks among the top ten worldwide. Located within Ocean Expo Park on the Motobu Peninsula, it opened in 2002 and attracts millions of visitors annually.

The aquarium's highlight is the enormous Kuroshio Sea tank, holding 7,500 tons of seawater behind 60-centimeter thick acrylic glass. It houses whale sharks up to 8.8 meters in length, along with manta rays and numerous species of fish. The aquarium was the first in the world to successfully breed manta rays in captivity.

The four-level facility features exhibits recreating Okinawa's tropical sea bottom, dedicated shark tanks, and displays of deep-sea creatures. Outside, visitors can enjoy dolphin shows, sea turtle exhibits, and the beautiful Emerald Beach nearby.

name: Naminoue Shrine
short_description: Okinawa's most important Shinto shrine, perched on a dramatic cliff overlooking Naminoue Beach and the ocean.
description:
Naminoue Shrine is the ichinomiya (primary shrine) of Okinawa Prefecture, sitting atop a high bluff overlooking Naminoue Beach and the East China Sea. Its name means 'above the waves' in Japanese, perfectly describing its dramatic clifftop location.

Originally a sacred space of the native Ryukyuan religion dedicated to nirai kanai (the mythical source of all life), the shrine has been revered for centuries. During the Ryukyu Kingdom era, it served as the most important shrine in the kingdom, where sailors prayed for safe voyages and the king himself visited annually to pray for national prosperity.

The shrine was destroyed during the Battle of Okinawa in 1945 and rebuilt in stages, with the main hall completed in 1953 and other buildings by 1993. The vermilion worship hall and the unique blend of Okinawan and Japanese architectural elements make it a distinctive spiritual site.

name: Kokusai Street (Kokusaidori)
short_description: Naha's famous 1.6-kilometer shopping and entertainment street lined with restaurants, souvenir shops, and live music venues.
description:
Kokusai Street is Naha's main tourist and shopping street, stretching for approximately 1.6 kilometers through downtown. Known as the 'Miracle Mile,' it takes its name from the former Ernie Pyle International Theater that was built here after World War II.

The street is lined with over 600 establishments including restaurants serving Okinawan cuisine, cafes, bars, hotels, souvenir shops selling shisa statues and local crafts, and boutiques. Many shops remain open until 10pm, and traditional Okinawan music is played live at several restaurants. Saturday nights are particularly lively with street performers.

Branching off Kokusai Street are the colorful Heiwadori, Mutsumidori, and Ichiba Hondori covered shopping arcades, offering smaller traditional shops and leading to the famous Makishi Public Market. Every Sunday from noon to 6pm, part of the street becomes car-free for the Transit Mall event.

name: Peace Memorial Park
short_description: Solemn memorial park commemorating the Battle of Okinawa, featuring the Cornerstone of Peace with over 240,000 names inscribed.
description:
Peace Memorial Park is located on Mabuni Hill in Itoman City, the site where the Battle of Okinawa ended in 1945. This battle, known as the 'Typhoon of Steel,' resulted in over 200,000 casualties and was one of the bloodiest conflicts of World War II.

The park's most iconic feature is the Cornerstone of Peace, unveiled in 1995, consisting of large black granite walls arranged in concentric arcs. These walls are inscribed with the names of all those who lost their lives in the battle, regardless of nationality or military/civilian status, currently bearing over 240,000 names.

The Okinawa Prefectural Peace Memorial Museum provides a sobering overview of the battle through photographs, artifacts, testimonials, and dioramas. Other features include the 45-meter-tall Okinawa Peace Hall housing a statue dedicated to world peace, the Eternal Flame of Peace, and memorial areas from each of Japan's 47 prefectures.

name: Sefa Utaki
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage Site and Okinawa's most sacred spiritual site, a forested sanctuary with ancient rock formations.
description:
Sefa Utaki is the most sacred site in Okinawa's indigenous religion, a historical sacred space that has served as a key location of worship for millennia. It overlooks Kudaka Island, believed to be where the ancestral goddess Amamikiyo first descended to create the Ryukyu Islands.

The sanctuary comprises dense subtropical forests and rugged rock formations, including six ibi (prayer sites) connected by walking trails. The most famous is Sangui, a triangular tunnel formed by two massive rocks leaning against each other, where stalactites drip sacred water into urns below.

During the Ryukyu Kingdom era, this was the kingdom's most sacred spot, managed by the highest priestess. Commoners were forbidden entry, and even kings had to dress in women's clothing to enter. Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000, it attracts about 400,000 visitors annually while remaining a living spiritual connection for local people.

name: Okinawa World
short_description: Theme park featuring Japan's second-longest limestone cave, a traditional Ryukyu village with craft workshops, and the Habu snake museum.
description:
Okinawa World is a comprehensive theme park about Okinawan culture located in the southern part of the main island. The park consists of three distinct areas: Gyokusendo Cave, the Kingdom Village, and the Habu Museum Park.

Gyokusendo Cave is the highlight - a 5-kilometer limestone cave system formed over 300,000 years, with 850 meters open to the public. Featuring spectacular stalactites and stalagmites, an underground river, and year-round temperatures around 21°C, it's the second longest cave in Japan.

The Kingdom Village recreates a traditional Ryukyu village with workshops demonstrating various Okinawan crafts including weaving, dyeing, paper making, pottery, and glass blowing. Daily performances of Super Eisa traditional folk dances are held on a covered outdoor stage. The Habu Museum Park features shows about Okinawa's venomous pit viper, held three times daily.

name: Cape Manzamo
short_description: Iconic scenic cliff formation resembling an elephant's trunk, offering stunning views of the East China Sea.
description:
Cape Manzamo is one of Okinawa's most popular natural landmarks, a dramatic 20-meter-high coral limestone cliff on the west coast facing the East China Sea. The name translates to 'a field for 10,000 people to sit,' reportedly coined by King Sho Kei during a royal visit in 1726.

The iconic elephant trunk-shaped rock formation has been sculpted by centuries of ocean erosion and is particularly photogenic against the cobalt-blue sea. The grassy plateau atop the cliff is home to rare native plants designated as a Natural Monument of Okinawa Prefecture.

The area is especially popular at sunset when the sky is painted in vibrant hues of orange and pink. The Manzamo Tourist Facility opened in 2020, offering shops selling local specialties on the first floor, a food court on the second floor, and a free observation deck on the third floor with panoramic views. A small 100 yen fee is charged for environmental conservation.

name: Okinawa Prefectural Museum and Art Museum
short_description: Comprehensive museum complex exploring Okinawa's unique history, nature, and art, housed in a striking castle-inspired building.
description:
The Okinawa Prefectural Museum and Art Museum, known as OkiMu, is a comprehensive facility in the Omoromachi district that opened in 2007. The striking building, constructed largely of local Okinawan limestone, was designed with the imagery of traditional gusuku castles in mind.

The museum section explores Okinawa's unique history, archaeology, nature, folklore, and arts and crafts through five exhibition rooms. Entering via a glass-floored walkway designed to look like walking over coral, visitors discover exhibits explaining Okinawa's distinct culture from the perspectives of 'Ocean' and 'Archipelago.'

The art museum focuses on modern and contemporary works by Okinawan artists or those with connections to Okinawa, including paintings, sculptures, calligraphy, and installations. The complex also features traditional Okinawan buildings in the courtyard, a sculpture garden, cafe, museum shop, and hands-on experience room.

name: Makishi Public Market
short_description: Vibrant traditional market selling fresh seafood, pork, and local produce, with upstairs restaurants that cook your purchases.
description:
Makishi Public Market, also known as Naha's Kitchen, is the central produce, meat, fish, and general merchandise market located just off Kokusai Street. Established in 1951, it has been renovated and reopened in 2023 with a fresh new look while maintaining its authentic atmosphere.

The first floor features vendors selling all kinds of Okinawan foodstuffs: colorful tropical fish, lobster and shellfish in tanks, pork including pig's face, feet, and stomach, unique vegetables like goya (bitter melon) and hechima (sponge gourd), and tropical fruits delivered directly from farms.

A unique experience called 'lifting' allows visitors to purchase seafood on the first floor and have it cooked at the second-floor restaurants for a small fee. The surrounding alleys feature stand-up-style shops selling fresh tempura, steamed cakes, and goya juice. The market embodies the Okinawan spirit of 'ichariba chode' - once we meet, we are like brothers and sisters.

name: Kouri Island
short_description: Romantic 'Island of Love' connected by a stunning 2km bridge, featuring crystal-clear beaches and the famous Heart Rocks.
description:
Kouri Island is a small, circular island with a radius of just one kilometer, located in the coastal waters off the Motobu Peninsula. Connected to the main island since 2005 via the 1,960-meter Kouri Bridge - the second longest toll-free bridge in Okinawa - it's known locally as 'Love Island.'

The island is famous for its exceptionally transparent emerald-green waters, considered some of the clearest in Okinawa. Kouri Beach at the base of the bridge is the most popular spot, while Tinu Beach on the north side features the famous Heart Rocks - two naturally heart-shaped rock formations sculpted by the waves.

Okinawan folklore connects the island to a creation legend similar to Adam and Eve, with two ancestors of mankind said to have lived in a sea cave here. The Kouri Ocean Tower offers panoramic views from 82 meters above sea level, while the island's quiet beaches and traditional landscapes provide a peaceful escape.

name: Nakijin Castle Ruins
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage Site featuring impressive 14th-century gusuku walls winding along a hilltop with panoramic ocean views.
description:
Nakijin Castle is one of Okinawa's most impressive gusuku (castle) ruins, located on the Motobu Peninsula. Dating back to the 13th century, it was the residence of the lord of Hokuzan, one of three kingdoms that competed for control of Okinawa before unification in 1429.

The castle's most striking feature is its outer wall, which stretches 1.5 kilometers and is sometimes called the 'Great Wall of Okinawa.' Unlike the angular walls of Japanese castles, Nakijin's walls follow natural contours in graceful curves, built from local limestone without mortar using a technique unique to Okinawa.

Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000 as part of the Gusuku Sites and Related Properties of the Kingdom of Ryukyu, the ruins offer spectacular views of the East China Sea. The site is particularly beautiful during the annual cherry blossom festival in late January to early February, when the castle walls are illuminated and pink hikanzakura flowers bloom.

name: American Village
short_description: Colorful entertainment complex with a distinctive American atmosphere, featuring shops, restaurants, a Ferris wheel, and sunset beach.
description:
American Village is a large entertainment and shopping complex in Chatan Town, built on reclaimed land that was formerly part of a US military facility. The area has a distinctive American atmosphere, reflecting Okinawa's unique blend of Japanese and American cultures.

The complex features numerous shops, restaurants, cafes, nightclubs, and entertainment facilities including a movie theater and the iconic Ferris wheel. The architecture is colorful and eclectic, with some buildings designed to evoke California beach towns. Adjacent to the village is Sunset Beach, a man-made beach popular for watching spectacular sunsets over the East China Sea.

American Village is particularly popular with young people and comes alive at night with its neon-lit buildings and lively atmosphere. The area is a cultural artifact of sorts, embodying the fusion of American and Okinawan influences that has developed over decades of US military presence on the island.

name: Emerald Beach
short_description: Award-winning beach within Ocean Expo Park featuring pristine white sand and shallow, calm waters perfect for families.
description:
Emerald Beach is a beautiful crescent-shaped beach located within Ocean Expo Park, near the Churaumi Aquarium on the Motobu Peninsula. Listed among Japan's top 100 beaches, it offers pristine white coral sand and crystal-clear emerald waters.

The beach is divided into three sections: a swimming area with calm, shallow waters perfect for families with children, a viewing area for those who want to relax and enjoy the scenery, and a sunset viewing area. The water is exceptionally shallow, making it one of the safest beaches in Okinawa for young children.

Facilities include showers, changing rooms, and rental equipment for marine activities. The beach offers stunning views of Ie Island (Iejima) with its distinctive Gusuku Mountain across the water. Entry to the beach is free as part of Ocean Expo Park, making it an ideal combination with a visit to the nearby aquarium.

name: Tsuboya Pottery District
short_description: Historic pottery district with traditional workshops, galleries, and the Tsuboya Pottery Museum showcasing Okinawan yachimun ceramics.
description:
Tsuboya is Naha's historic pottery district, a center of ceramic production since 1682 when Ryukyu kilns were consolidated here by royal decree. The narrow streets are lined with pottery shops, workshops, and galleries selling traditional Okinawan ceramics known as yachimun.

Tsuboya pottery is characterized by its earthy colors and distinctive patterns, including the iconic shisa lion-dog figures that guard Okinawan homes. Visitors can watch artisans at work, purchase unique pieces directly from makers, and even try their hand at pottery in some workshops.

The excellent Tsuboya Pottery Museum houses fine examples of traditional Okinawan pottery and provides context for the craft's history. The cobblestone Suuji Path (Yachimun Street) winds through the district, passing traditional stone walls and old climbing kilns. Some pottery studios have been operating continuously for generations, maintaining techniques passed down through centuries.

name: Former Japanese Navy Underground Headquarters
short_description: Haunting WWII underground tunnels where 4,000 Japanese soldiers died, preserving hand grenade damage on the walls.
description:
The Former Japanese Navy Underground Headquarters is a sobering WWII memorial site located in Kaigungō Park, just south of central Naha. This network of underground tunnels and rooms served as the command center for the Japanese Navy during the final stages of the Battle of Okinawa.

The headquarters was carved out by hand by approximately 3,000 soldiers, stretching for several hundred meters underground. About 4,000 men died here, many by their own hand as American forces closed in. The walls still bear visible damage from hand grenades used in mass suicides, and some rooms retain their original wartime function signs.

Visitors can explore about 300 meters of the restored tunnels, passing through the commander's room, staff room, cipher room, and other chambers. The site offers a powerful and emotional reminder of the human cost of war. A small museum at the entrance provides historical context about the battle and its devastating impact on Okinawa.

name: Tamaudun Mausoleum
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage Site housing the royal tombs of the Second Shō Dynasty, featuring distinctive stone architecture.
description:
Tamaudun is the royal mausoleum of the Ryukyu Kingdom, located adjacent to Shuri Castle. Built in 1501 by King Shō Shin, it served as the final resting place for 17 kings of the Second Shō Dynasty, along with their queens and royal children.

The mausoleum's distinctive architecture consists of three connected chambers carved into a coral limestone cliff, with the facade designed to resemble a wooden building. The central chamber was used for temporary interment, while the left chamber held the remains of kings and queens, and the right chamber was for princes and princesses.

Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000 as part of the Gusuku Sites and Related Properties of the Kingdom of Ryukyu, Tamaudun survived the Battle of Okinawa with relatively minor damage. The site includes a small museum displaying artifacts and explaining the burial customs of the Ryukyu royal family. A stone stele at the entrance designates who may be entombed within.

name: Naminoue Beach
short_description: Naha's only city beach, located directly below Naminoue Shrine with views of the cliff-top shrine from the sand.
description:
Naminoue Beach is the only beach within Naha City, making it a convenient spot for visitors to enjoy Okinawa's ocean without traveling far from the urban center. Located directly below Naminoue Shrine, the beach offers a unique combination of sun, sand, and spirituality.

The beach features white coral sand and clear blue waters, though it's considerably smaller than Okinawa's more famous resort beaches. Looking up from the sand, visitors can see Naminoue Shrine perched dramatically on the cliff above - a view that has been photographed countless times.

Facilities include changing rooms, showers, lockers, and beach equipment rentals. The swimming season runs from April to October when lifeguards are on duty and jellyfish nets are in place. The beach is accessible by monorail and a short walk, and many visitors combine a beach visit with exploring nearby Kokusai Street and the shrine above.

name: Southeast Botanical Gardens
short_description: Tropical botanical gardens with over 1,300 plant varieties from around the world, featuring a lake, water buffalo, and exotic birds.
description:
Southeast Botanical Gardens is a lush tropical paradise in Okinawa City with a history spanning over 50 years. The gardens showcase more than 1,300 varieties of plants from Okinawa and tropical regions around the world, arranged in beautifully landscaped grounds.

Visitors can explore themed areas including a palm garden, flowering tree garden, herb garden, and water lily pond. The gardens are home to various animals including gentle water buffalo that can be seen near the lake, colorful tropical birds, and small animals in the petting area - making it popular with families.

The gardens are especially beautiful during flowering seasons, with different plants blooming throughout the year. Seasonal illumination events transform the gardens after dark. A café and restaurant on site serve food and drinks featuring local ingredients, and a gift shop offers plant-related souvenirs and Okinawan crafts.

name: Ryukyu Mura
short_description: Living history village recreating traditional Ryukyu Kingdom life with relocated historic houses, craft workshops, and cultural performances.
description:
Ryukyu Mura is a theme village recreating the lifestyle of the ancient Ryukyu Kingdom, located in Onna Village in central Okinawa. The park features authentic traditional houses that were relocated from various parts of the island, including several registered as Tangible Cultural Properties.

Visitors can experience traditional Okinawan culture firsthand through various workshops including bingata dyeing, pottery making, sanshin (three-stringed instrument) playing, and traditional weaving. Traditional Eisa dance and folk music performances are held throughout the day on the village's main stage.

The red-tiled traditional houses are arranged along village paths, creating an authentic atmosphere of old Okinawa. Each house has been carefully preserved and often demonstrates a particular aspect of traditional life. The village also hosts special events during festivals and holidays, celebrating Okinawan traditions that continue to this day.

name: Cape Zanpa
short_description: Dramatic 30-meter cliffs with a historic white lighthouse offering panoramic ocean views and excellent sunset watching.
description:
Cape Zanpa is a scenic coastal area in Yomitan Village featuring dramatic 30-meter-high limestone cliffs stretching for about 2 kilometers along the East China Sea. The area is designated as a national park and offers some of the most spectacular coastal scenery in Okinawa.

The iconic white Zanpa Lighthouse, built in 1974, stands 31 meters tall at the tip of the cape. Visitors can climb to the observation deck for panoramic views of the ocean, and on clear days, the distant islands of Kume and Kerama are visible. The lighthouse is one of only 16 in Japan that allows public climbing.

The grassy areas around the cape feature walking paths, a large shisa statue, and picnic spots popular with locals. The area is famous for whale watching during winter months and for viewing spectacular sunsets year-round. Nearby, the ruins of Zakimi Castle (also a UNESCO World Heritage Site) add historical interest to the area.

name: Fukushuen Garden
short_description: Elegant Chinese-style garden built to commemorate Naha's sister-city relationship with Fuzhou, featuring pavilions, bridges, and a waterfall.
description:
Fukushuen (Garden of Happiness) is a beautiful Chinese-style garden located in Naha, built in 1992 to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the sister-city relationship between Naha and Fuzhou, China. The garden reflects the deep historical ties between the Ryukyu Kingdom and China.

Spanning about 8,500 square meters, the garden was designed and constructed with the cooperation of Fuzhou artisans. It features traditional Fuzhou-style architecture including pavilions, arched bridges, a waterfall, and a pond stocked with colorful koi fish. The buildings showcase traditional Chinese techniques such as intricate wooden lattice work and upturned eaves.

A royal villa that belonged to the Ryukyu royal family has been reconstructed within the garden, adding a unique Okinawan element. The garden is particularly beautiful during azalea season in spring and offers a peaceful respite from the nearby urban bustle of Kokusai Street, just a short walk away.

name: Blue Cave (Maeda Point)
short_description: Famous sea cave illuminated by brilliant blue light, one of Okinawa's most popular snorkeling and diving destinations.
description:
The Blue Cave at Maeda Point is one of Okinawa's most famous natural attractions, a partially submerged sea cave where sunlight refracts through the water to create an ethereal blue glow. Located on the coast of Onna Village, it has become one of Japan's most popular snorkeling and diving destinations.

The cave extends about 30 meters into the cliff, with water depths ranging from about 5 to 10 meters. When sunlight enters through the cave opening and reflects off the white sandy bottom, the water appears to glow an intense, almost electric blue. The phenomenon is most vivid during morning hours when the sun angle is optimal.

Numerous tour operators offer guided snorkeling and diving trips to the cave, suitable for beginners and experienced divers alike. The surrounding waters are rich in marine life including tropical fish, sea cucumbers, and occasionally sea turtles. Access to the cave is possible by swimming from shore or by boat, with the stairs at Maeda Point being the most common entry point.

name: Yanbaru National Park
short_description: UNESCO Natural Heritage Site protecting subtropical forests home to endemic species like the Okinawa rail and Yanbaru long-armed scarab beetle.
description:
Yanbaru National Park covers approximately 14,000 hectares in the northern part of Okinawa's main island, protecting one of the largest remaining subtropical laurel forests in Japan. In 2021, it was inscribed as a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site for its outstanding biodiversity.

The park is home to many endemic species found nowhere else on Earth, including the Yanbaru kuina (Okinawa rail), a flightless bird discovered only in 1981, the Yanbaru long-armed scarab beetle, and numerous unique plants and amphibians. The varied landscape includes dense forests, karst limestone formations, mangrove forests, and rugged coastline.

Popular activities include hiking through the forest trails, kayaking through mangrove estuaries, bird watching, and visiting the Hiji Otaki (Hiji Falls), a 26-meter waterfall accessible via a forest trail. The area offers a stark contrast to the beach resorts of central Okinawa, showcasing the island's wild, mountainous interior.

name: Himeyuri Peace Museum
short_description: Poignant museum commemorating high school girls who served as nurses during the Battle of Okinawa, most of whom died.
description:
The Himeyuri Peace Museum stands above a cave that served as an emergency field hospital during the closing days of the Battle of Okinawa. It commemorates the tragic fate of the Himeyuri Student Corps - 222 female high school students and 18 teachers from two Okinawan schools who were mobilized to work as nurses.

The students, aged 15-19, worked in underground surgical wards under horrific conditions, tending to wounded soldiers without adequate supplies or training. When the Japanese military dissolved the nursing units with the battle lost, the girls were suddenly thrust onto the battlefield. Of the 240 corps members, 136 died, many in the immediate aftermath of the dissolution order.

The museum displays photographs, personal belongings, and testimonies of the students, providing an intimate and emotional perspective on the human cost of war. The adjacent Himeyuri Monument marks the cave entrance where many died. It stands as one of Okinawa's most visited peace sites.
